bibl.title: Letter from James E. Peabody to the Members of the New York Association of Biology Teachers, May 5, 1935

div1.p: Peabody urges support of a bill granting posthumous recognition to George Sherman Ward and a pension to his survivors, in recognition of Ward's part in James Carroll's typhoid experiment, in 1904.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to the Members of the New York Association of Biology Teachers, May 5, 1935
div1.opener:
FROM JAMES E. PEABODY
To the Members of the New York Association of Biology Teachers:
div1.p:
On the last evening of April I attended the funeral of George Sherman
Ward at the Columbus Chapel in New York. It is probable that no one of you
ever heard of Ward. Neither had I until my visit with my good friends,
General Kean and General KeanGilchrist in Washington on my way home from Florida.

Our Biology Association has the proud record of leadership in securing
in 1929 the passage by Congress of the Bill to give perpetual honor, a gold medal
and a pensions of $1800 a year to each of those 22 men who were engaged in those
momentous yellow fever demonstrations in Cuba in 1900. I therefore venture to
call your attention to the story of a man who surely deserves to be classed
with John R. Kissinger, and John J. Moran, as a volunteer in the cause of science.
Ward's story, briefly told, is as follows.

Back in 1904 Dr. James Carroll, one of the four members of the Yellow Fever
Board, was confident he had developed an anti-typhoid serum. He had tried it
on rabbits and guinea pigs, but he needed human beings to experiment upon
before publishing his discovery. Ten men volunteered for this service and
they were given through the mouth the anti-typhoid serum diluted in water.
It was later proved that the mixture had been imperfectly sterilized. All
but two of the men (they had previously had typhoid fever) were stricken with
the disease, and some of them barely escaped death.

The account of these experiments has never been published because of the
effect it would have on the army medical service. Recently, however, Gen-
eral Gilchrist has prepared a complete report, and has included a statement
of the experiences of each of the volunteers. Ten years after Carroll's
experiments the present method of intra-venous injection was perfected by
General F. F. Russell, now Chairman of the International Health Board of the
Rockefeller Foundation.

One of the volunteers in that unfortunate experiment of 1904 was George S.
Ward. He has suffered from his experiences, especially during these later
years. Senator Copeland, who sponsored our Yellow Fever Bill in the Senate,
introduced a bill to give Mr. Ward the $125 a month pension which the yellow
fever heroes or their widows and the widow of Dr. Goldberger have been re-
ceiving. I found on visiting Senator Copeland's office that there is little
hope that this bill will be passed. General Gilchrist, however, writes me
as follows after receiving my letter informing him of Ward's death: “I intend
to work just as hard for the passage of Ward's Bill. Although the recognition
must be pos a posthumous one, it may be a great help to the members of his
immediate family.”

I hesitate to suggest that our Biology Association might be able to help
in this most worthy cause. Mr. S. L. Frooks, of the firm of Frooks and Frooks,
369 Lexington Avenue, who has worked devotedly to secure assistance for Ward,
as well as General H. L. Gilchrist of the Army Mediacl Museum, Washington, D. C.
will be able to give all information needed. Cannot you biology teachers in
your classes at least pay tribute to this another hero who volunteered in the
service for humanity, and who at the age of 54 has passed from among us?
div1.closer:
James E. Peabody (formerly at Morris High Sch
Ashburnham, Mass., May 5th., 1935.
